												100% better than 2k15, I love the new limited reversal system, it makes the game fun and challenging and it can be turned off if you don't like it. I'm actually able to use strike in this game more than once before it is reversed which is a milestone for me! Some of my matches have been classic back and forth, mutiple finishers, mutiple close pins, just the overall feeling of at any point the momentum can change, and it will, very true to life wrestling. 												This is a bizarre mix of great and awful elements. The Showcase mode is stellar, the editor is remarkably detailed, there is an exceptional amount of content and it all runs beautifully.Unfortunately, this is let down by other aspects of the game. The commentary is so far short of the NBA series as to be embarassing. It's buggy (incorrect lines are often spoken, and sometimes the same line is repeated several times in a row) and there are times when the commentator is clearly reading from a script (particularly Cole). Some lines are recorded at a different volume, and sound like they were literally phoned in.The AI is wonky at best, and when combined with the awkward hit detection and inconsistent ability to interrupt animations, multi-man matches become an absolute trainwreck where AI teammates constantly interfere with each other. Several of the achievements do not trigger properly.Game concepts are explained poorly, no effort is made for a manual or tutorial. Not ideal when the series is new to PC.The career mode is built around grinding; even though this version comes with DLC to at least boost your character (albeit buried away in a menu - I wasted plenty of time before noticing it), it is still a painful slog through match after match against the same opponent - aggravated by the nonsense Authority objectives, some of which are rendered impossible by circumstances out of your control. Oh, and on career mode, it baffles me how an otherwise great-looking game reduced Renee Young to a plastic, Uncanny Valley resident.It's frustrating because this could be a great game, and elements of it are outstanding, but it's just let down by so many needless flaws.Oh, and I didn't miss 2K's continued gouging of Australians, either - a 30% mark-up is a disgrace.

												As a PC gamer, it's been an incredibly long time since I have played a WWE game. Although I've played just an hour of game play, I will edit the review when more hours have gone into playing it. First off, I'm pretty impressed with the visuals on some of the superstar models, especially Randy Orton, however I do feel there is some inconsistences amongst the models, some looking like they're from the PS3 (Jericho being a prime example of this) and not next gen. The game is not the best optimized, I have a beast of a laptop running games like Witcher 3, The Division, Rise of the Tomb Raider on ultra, hitting 60 fps with WWE2k16 on maximum I'm hitting on average 50, but patches will more than likely fix this in the future, after all it's not even been out a full 24 hours yet. The creation mod looks good and glad they've put back a lot that was meant to be taken out the previous game. I've only briefly touched on the Universe mode, which I have enjoyed so far. Overall I think this is decent game, with future patches having the possibility of making it a really good game, once fps is smoother. I still stand by the showcase being great and is arguably the best feature in this game. Althought the Hall of Fame showcase is not as good as the Stone Cold showcase, it is still good to play classic matches such as Macho Man v my favourite wrestler of all time, Jake "the snake" Roberts. 												While I'm recommending this game based on what's here, I have to also talk about why I WON'T be buying another WWE game from 2K until they make some changes.First off, the game IS a bit buggy at launch and it may run, or it may not. Every single time you click "Play" it's a toss-up whether or not the game will launch. Once it launches, I'm good with 60 fps at Ultra, but whether or not the game starts up at all is the question. Second, it absolutely ticks me off that we PC users don't get the ability to use custom music. There's no reason the restrictions of the consoles should remain for the PC version. We don't get stuck with the console graphics, but we do get stuck with the console limits on custom music. This is a DEAL BREAKER for me. I make leagues of my own CAWs, and if I can't give them custom music, that's half of the pro wrestling experience completely thrown out the window. Sure, modders will make it possible, but I shouldn't have to mod the game to get what I want out of it when it comes to something as basic and integral as entrance music. It would be NO BIG DEAL for the game to let us point to a folder full of MP3 files, but they're simply not allowing it. That stinks, and it's the big reason why I won't be purchasing 2K17 for PC (or anything else) until I hear that Yukes/2K put the ability to assign custom music to CAWs back into the game. It's ridiculous that I would rather go back and play my league on 2K14 for Xbox 360 because it is technically inferior to 2K16 in terms of customization! Another big problem is the submission mini-game. It just sucks, and the AI almost always has the advantage, it seems. It doesn't even make a lot of sense, and I find myself missing the old submission method. Again, 2K14 is making me happy where 2K16 does not. If only I could get 2K14 on my PC.What 2K16 does have is great animation, excellent graphics, and a more streamlined (though more limited) creation suite. I'm currently debating if these advances are enough to make me keep this game. Frankly, I'm still pretty ticked about the lack of custom music and I've been two seconds away from hitting the "submit" button on a refund. The only thing keeping me interested is the exceptionally nice look to this game. But graphics aren't everything, and while the models all look great, they still don't look photorealistic, and in the end I can probably be happy with my 2K14. So I continue to debate over the value of 2K16 to me. If you're a fan of the WWE and all the "superstars" and "divas" in their roster, then you'll probably love this game. Me? I *really* don't care about the WWE characters and would much rather play my own. When some company makes a game like this that doesn't have any licensed characters and instead lets CAW fans make their own leagues, I'll buy two copies (if it's any good). Sadly, I think the thing that ultimately ruins this series for me is the WWE licensing, which seems to be pretty restrictive when it comes to customizing features. That's all I can conclude, anyway, because there is NO TECHNICAL REASON why WWE 2K16 wouldn't support custom music or other customizing features that are missing. So many names were removed from the announcements, so many clothing pieces, so many types of makeup, face paint, etc. and worst of all, on the PC we STILL have to go through the stupid upload process to get logos and faces into the game. WE'RE ON A PC! Why should I need to send something from my PC, to the web site, then get into the game and download it again when it WAS ON MY PC IN THE FIRST PLACE?! This is just so stupid!Why can't I get a Fire Pro Wrestling game like this one, yet with all FPW's customization? I suspect the glitches and bugs will be squashed and eventually the game will start up when you click "Play" instead of tossing a coin and deciding at that time whether or not you'll get to play. I doubt, however, that 2K gives a crap about patching in custom music.GET IT TOGETHER, 2K.  This is the PC, not a console, and we want CUSTOMIZATION. You won't get another dime out of me until you wake up and support the CAW fans, too. Consider it a thumbs up if you only want to play within the WWE using their characters or characters that fit the really strict creation content (limited names, no music, limited clothing, limited body sizing, etc), but a big thumbs down if you're a CAW fan. They really disappointed me with this one. I'm getting the refund and going back to 2K14 on my 360.UPDATE:  Steam denied my refund request because "play time" was past 2 hours. Unfortunately, much of that time was the game "running" in the background (unbeknownst to me) after it had crashed on start-up. This IS a continuing issue with this game. Feel free to check the discussions and other tech support requests. My actual time in game was no doubt under 2 hours. My time trying to load it, trying to troubleshoot it, and dealing with technical issues was over 2 hours.  I do not think 6 hours of troubleshooting and digging into the game to see what's working and what's not working, and what's missing, is "significant playtime". Anyway, if you're having doubt about the game, get your refund ASAP. Steam doesn't seem to care that the game process continues to run after crashing, or that the game fails to make it clear that they've completely stripped the creation suite, prior to purchase. I feel like I got ripped off by 2K, here. Enjoy your 45 bucks, guys. I'll seriously reconsider purchasing any 2K title after this.

EDIT 03/06/16: The game has been patched and all of the issues I had have been fixed. Now I absolutely recommend this game without hesitation! (Original review)[pastebin.com]Last year we finally got a WWE licensed wrestling game on PC in over a decade, but it was a fairly mediocore game. 2K16 is a huge step up from that - It reintroduces many features that were missing, has a much larger roster and online is greatly improved.In fact this is one of my all time favourite pro wrestling games. If you're a fan of the old school Smackdown or N64 games then beware that this is a much more simulation focused game. It's a lot more slow paced and more unforgiving but that allows for more strategic gameplay. With stamina you can't endlessly run away, and you may have to decide to rest a little following a big move rather than hitting another with no stamina left for a quick pin. There's also limited reversals this time and THANK GOD. FINALLY matches aren't just an endless chain of reversals anymore.If you dislike any of that then everything can be customised; turn off stamina, reversal slots, adjust finisher damage etc. Also this year's game brings back features like Create An Arena and a much improved Create a Wrestler. (You can create females again! Yay!) The roster is massive and includes past and current wrestlers including some from NXT. Entrances are the best I have ever seen and are now completely seemless which allows you to interfere during your opponent's entrance! Awesome!It still suffers from Yearly Franchise Syndrome™ which includes plenty of minor bugs and glitches and some strange roster ommisions like Sasha Banks and Charlotte even though Blake and Murphy are somehow in the game. And for some reason you can't use your own entrance music even though you could do it in the last gen console games. Commentary is also as bland as ever and feels like it hasn't improved since Smackdown Vs Raw 2006.However it is entirely modabble! There was tons of great mods last year from updating wrestler's attire and entrances to entirely new arenas, and this year is no exception. Check out Smacktalks[smacktalks.org] for tons of great mods including tutorials on how to mod the game to use your own custom entrance music.[smacktalks.org]

												This game is an awesome wrestling simulator. I've only played one other wrestling game before this and that was WWE All Stars on the Xbox so when I began playing this I noticed it was completely different and people will eithr love it or hate it. So i'll tell you my experience with this game and you can be the judge whether it's worth a try. Initially my first week with this game was frustrating as I couldn't pick up the controls because there is literally no tutorial in this game; you have to pick it up and learn it for yourself. I found myself looking online to be able to use certain moves and certain grappling techniques. However after spending enough time on this game (as you can see from my hours) I would highly recommend it. After the learning curve I found this game to be extremely enjoyable, granted it can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥at first (have fun mastering the reversals) it is a fun and enjoyable wrestling game. There are 100+ wrestlers to play as (male AND female) and also the option to download custom made wrestlers by the community who didn't make it into the game eg; AJ Styles, CM Punk, Shinsuke Nakamura, Batman (i'm not even kidding)There are five different types of play modes available in this game.Play - Allows you to setup any match and play it in whatever ring with any of the wrestlers eg; Kofi Kingston vs The Rock at Raw with Hell in a Cell. This mode is fun as it allows you to make any match and is quite fun.My Career - Allows you to import a custom made wrestler or make a new one to play your own WWE career (WARNING: MAKE YOUR WRESTLER IN CREATIONS RATHER THAN MAKING IT IN MY CAREER - YOU CAN'T PLAY YOUR WRESTLER OUTSIDE OF MY CAREER IF YOU MAKE IT THERE RATHER THAN IMPORTING IT) This mode although fun at first can become boring and repetitve fast. After completing NXT you have the option for any of the main titles (Titles before the brand split). I found myself facing the same people over and over again which became boring after a while. The Career Mode is extremely basic and is not where this game shines. You can make your own rivalries and create a tag team with another wretler as well as having a manager if that takes your liking. Oh and you can't play as a woman wrestler.Showcase Mode - Basically allows you to play through Stone Cold Steve Austin's career. This mode is fun as it gives you objectives to do during the match (eg; attack opponent by ringside) which allows you to unlock extra characters. (although with the PC version you can just unlock everything anyway) It's fun but nothing i've sunk hours into.Universe Mode - Create your own shows, PPV's, Championships for shows, rivalries, tag teams. All that stuff. It's fun I guess but I often found myself skipping the shows and playing the PPV's only.Online Play - Buggy and laggy as hell - avoid it.As mentioned before you can download your own wrestlers from the creations tab and play as them in the "Play" and "Universe Mode". This is where the game is most fun. Although the game features a lot of wrestlers to play off the bat I enjoy getting the custom ring gear for wrestlers and play as them in the "Play" and "Universe Mode".So if you're willing to learn the controls and want a fun wrestling simulator i'd recommend this game. If you're not willing to spent the time to learn what this game has to offer and want a game you can learn in five minutes then this isn't for you.

												Short version: This is no different to last year. The only change is now you have a set amount of reversals (that you regain over time) to avoid the ridiculous amont of reversals of yesteryear. Unless you REALLY love Showcase or somehow weren't bored of the Career or Universe mode's repetition, you won't miss this. It's probably better than what THQ would still be producing, but 2K are just like WWE - phoning it in now they have no competition. Why try?Long version:Exactly as I said in my review of last year's game, there are moments of huge potential hidden in here.The movement is so fluid nowadays that things look a notch more realistic (like playing a tag match as The Outsiders, and Hall slips out of a move and pushes the guy in your direction as you run up and deliver Nash's Big Boot finisher, beautiful).The tech is advanced enough to have physics for satisfying impacts on weapons and through tables now too (X-Pac's Super X-Factor onto a ladder or table you conveniently laid below is a bit more satisfying now, but not as much as setting up a table next to a ladder, fighting on top of the ladder, and powerbombing the guy off it in exactly the right place where you laid out the table, which you may or may not have set on fire beforehand.But it still needs a lot of tweaking. They're clearly aiming for the more thought-provoking game we once had around 2007, with stamina and limb damage and how it affected your moves, but they're still not there yet. Even when they do add things, there's no tutorial and no real manual so people are tasked to find out themselves what icons mean or how to do things.Another notable thing is finisher spamming and no-selling. Spamming finishers and kicking out of them has become cool. This has been replicated in the game, and it's just as ridiculous. Your matches can go 10 minutes too long because Rusev kicked out of his 10th F-5. It makes the health bars meaningless.Unfortunately the graphics have always been a generation behind. There's been no major graphical overhaul in this version, it's still cartoony, and the Divas are still creepy as hell and have ♥♥♥♥ed up Joker smiles. Funnily enough, Steph finally looks a lot like Steph now - she seems to have a face that's been impossible to recreate in digital form thus far.And how's the commentary? Well Cole, King and JBL are annoying as ever. They're all good guys ('faces') now, so they brown-nose everyone in the ring and spout hyperbole like how Kane and Daniel Bryan was "one of the most famous tag teams in history". They have conversations about the guys in the ring... then repeat THE SAME CONVERSATION a minute later. So kudos to 2K for accurately recreating their horrible, repetitive chatty commentary. Well King, if wishes were fishes...While the roster is large (mainly because of the Austin showcase adding random guys like Savio Vega and Mikey Whipwreck), #GiveDivasAChance didn't reach WWE 2K16 so women didn't get the same treatment. Basically the only women are Trish, Lita and all the usual names. No one new like Sasha Banks, Bayley or Charlotte nor the female legends like Victoria, Molly, Ivory or dare I say Chyna. And for some reason Emma has her cool heel theme but is still dancing like an idiot and her face looks like a puffy kawaii interpretation rather than her actual self. With added sunburn to her face.This year's Showcase has you play through an abridged version of Austin's WWE career (with a few bonus WCW and ECW matches). Haven't you done a bit of that before? Yes! You'll be replaying some of the matches you did in WWE 13's Attitude Era showcase!There's no big extra bonus showcase this time around either, just one where you play one match each as the Hall of Fame class of 2015. Relive those historic and proud moments like when Jake the Snake beat the everloving♥♥♥♥♥♥out of inductee Randy Savage while Miss Elizabeth screamed for him to stop, or the time Alundra Blayze faced Paige at WrestleMania 31, or you can relive Kevin Nash's career- and industry-changing moment when he and Scott Hall... faced Harlem Heat in a tag match.I always enjoyed Showcase mode (and it s predecessor Legends of WrestleMania), but it's not very interactive now. Here's how it goes now:1) You start a match2) 5-minute cutscene of entrances and opening moments of match, very slow-paced.3) Get given an objective as you start the match (e.g. irish whip your opponent, do your finisher, throw them out the ring), this can take anything from 3 seconds to a minute or two.4) Very slow-paced cutscene plays of what happened next in the match, this can be a few minutes, because they've got to show every second! You've now been sat here 10 minutes and only played for 2 of those minutes at most.4b) Sometimes there's a QTE, which means you spend 20 seconds watching the buttons waiting to see which flashes, so now you're not even watching the cutscenes!5) Go back to 3 until match is over.This is combined with the familiar half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥unemotional commentary from J.R. He and King are slightly more believable, but now just sound mildly interested. I picture them sitting on the sofa, feet up in front of the TV and commentating on the match to each other.My Career mode is where you create a guy and climb the ranks. In the last game it was just a load of meaningless matches, and it's not any different this time around. Again there's huge potential here. When I reached rank #1 for Kevin Owen's NXT title, I made sure my bosses (the game) gave me my shot by taking out Owens. He was having a match, so as he was doing his title pose during his entrance, I appeared into camera shot behind him, the crowd went mental, and I laid him out.When I got promoted to Raw, I needed to fast track myself to the title, so I made a statement by going after the #1 contender for the world title: Brock Lesnar! He was having a match, so as he was doing his little pose during his entance, I appeared into camera shot...Ah, you see where I'm going. That's the problem. You can go after people, make statements, do your thing, but there's only one way to do it, it's the same old♥♥♥♥♥♥ and there's no intricate storylines. Just as in Universe Mode, two guys beat each other up each week then have a PPV match. Same every month. Even if something major happens, like joining The Authority, it's like nothing happened, just a random cutscene that played.The unintentional highlight of this mode is the promos, delivered awfully and eerily similar to one of the Family Guy voices. 												It's better than 2k15 by miles, proving that the last release was probably worth skipping a release to get to this point. This is where i have most of my fun, nothing better than being the show runner and having the shows run how i want.The wrestling in the matches i have had are still very poor, messy and so, so glitchy. Little mechanic faults and immersion breaking animation trips. Is the character trying to pick another up but he's slightly out of reach? Watch him slide into place as if on ice... Is a wreslter next to an object or even on top of it? Sit back and watch the animation freak out before either giving up or just ignoring you did any button press. It's the 2016 version, how is it still so bad?The ropes seem to be a bug bear of the character models who spin around near them like they are electric. Getting in and out of the ring is still limited to the middle section or they freak out at lifes hard choice of weather you meant cclimb the turnbuckle, go to the apron or exit entireley, 2K need to have a little button reallocating. Even lifting an opponent from the floor can take some work as the character model struggles to comprehend what it is you've instucted it to do, often just looking down then stepping back.Everything in ring feels slower, not in a pacing way just a doddering way to keep the gameplay more 'realistic'. Sure it's realistic if you want to watch the Old age pensioner divison. Running around makes it seem like the players swapped their kneecaps for sponges and they are wearing moon boots. It's one of the ugliest movement animations I've seen in a game aiming for realisim. It's ugly, janky and cheap looking and pretty embarrasing, it's WWE it's already hard to explain to the missus why i still buy the games and still watch it... I've sweated with anger when the prompts of 'too fast' and 'too slow' pop on screen after reversing, I've sat emulating a Rocky montage trying to train my fingers to hit it right. I;'m convinced there is no real pattern, it's just what ever the game needs it to be at that moment.They've capped the amount of reversals you can do at once, which is a nice feature though i feel they would of been better served actually having to play the game once they release is so they can see just how pants the system is and always has been.It's 2016, as I'm reminded by said missus who once again asks why I like this soap opera... Why, why in the day sof 'Realistic action' can't i stop a taunt? Some of these dudes have entire dance routines as taunts which lead to your character helplessly doing the funky shuffle while a large fighter barrels towards you. In short the wrestling aspect of this game is it's worst feature, it's poor mechanics hindered by worse colision detection, AI and movement. 2K definately have not figured out how to do this type of action.Slightly less poo yet still on the scale of "ew what's on my shoe" it's the 'Showcase'. Which is still pretty much the laziest, most uninspired useless game mode. "Hey, remember all those great memories of when WWE was good? Here, play this and remind yourself why you didn't just subscribe to the Network instead" QTE moments which are epicly pointless, the QTE is not so much a 'Quick Time Event' but a 'watch this clip and press the button after a few minutes of an animation playing out' And you can't enjoy the animation of an event being recreated because have to focus on the button wheel at the bottom of the screen to catch the QTE. So what's the point?I know what they are doing, they want us to go back into our memories of when the product didn't feature Roman Reigns, and by having it fleshed out so poorly it will trick us into thinking we were just remembering it wrong and it did all suck. How many objectives per Showcase match do we have to meet? It's like a job i didn't apply for. 7 for the Bret Hart match alone, and some of the descriptions for the objectives are hilariously appauling.The roster is the biggest we've seen yet the oddest ommisions are glaring, the womens division gets clearly the worst treatment as the best names get dropped in favour of 2 types of sting and 4 Triple H's. He's definately going over.Customisation is amazing, the graphics are good for most of the character models although 2K still can't figure out long hair. 												Hell yes, I recommend WWE 2K16.  The only thing better than a good wrestling match is a good wrestling game, and 2K16 is such.  My biggest gripe is no mixed matches.I wasn't expecting to enjoy this as much as I have.  I thought at best, it'd be a fun little game to spend a few hours in.  I've put in more consecutive time here than I have Fallout 4.  At the time of writing this, I am still not burned out on it.PRO's:+Graphics are mostly terrific.  Some Superstars/Divas are spot on.  Others don't seem to have had as much attention to detail put into them (not that they're ugly, just that they aren't as good as the really good ones).  +Create modes. Holy isht, create modes.  Create Superstars, Divas, Entrances, Arenas, Shows, Titles... the CAW was always the draw to these games, and it has been greatly expanded upon here.  Face uploads make for creating anyone you can imagine without much effort, and with logo/texture uploads, you're really only limited by your imagination.+Sharing these creations is so easy now.  If you've used the Community Creations of The Sims 4, you'll feel right at home here.  Anything you create (even move-sets) can be uploaded and easily downloaded.  WWF CAW vets will appreciate this - no more writing down CAW parts!  Just share that sucker!+Match types.  Plenty of must-have matches have made a return.  TLC, Elimination Chamber, Hell in a Cell, Steel Cage, Royal Rumble, Last Man Standing, Submission, Battle Royal.  That's not to say they're perfect, which I'll get into in the Con's.+The Roster.  Largest roster to date in any WWE game, and arguably the best.  It reaches back into WWE history and presents dozens of favorites and familiars.  Some of these even have alternate attires or versions.  Add CAW's to the list, and you're looking at 200+ fighters.  <-Holy Strawberries, Batman, is that a jam!+Mechanics.  I spent time playing No Mercy and Day of Reckoning waiting for this release, and I wasn't sure how I'd feel about the leap from arcade to simulation.  It's not as bad as people say it is, and I usually hate QTE-type things, but I find them enjoyable here.  It's nice to have control over how you place and evade grapples/holds, and I feel missing the kick out of a pin because of poor timing adds to that "Oh, come on WWE, how could that happen?" feel you get watching the actual program sometimes.  And like No Mercy, the grapple system is multi-layered.  If you've played No Mercy, you know what I'm talking about.  It literally feels like they mashed No Mercy, Day of Reckoning, and Here Comes the Pain into one big, beautiful baby.+Customization.  This is the best part of the game.  In Universe mode, you can control who's in what show, who they face, and who their rivals are.  It's like a very hands-on Exhibition mode.  Outside of Universe, you can control how the game plays by toning down (or pumping up) the new simulation systems.  You can control what music plays in the main menu.  You can even tweak the individual Superstar/Diva stats, both in Exhibition and in Universe. CON's:-Some matches are not included as team sets.  For instance, I haven't seen any tag team TLC's.  Such a shame, as tag-team TLC was usually among me and mine's favorite match types.  It's a bit odd see it in singles, but not to see the beloved team version.  -Royal Rumble is gender-restricted.  2K16 does not feature a Diva Royal Rumble.  Surely there are enough Divas in the vanilla version to do a 10-woman rumble, but adding CAD's to it, and I see no reason the women couldn't have one.  At least they can do the other matches.-No mixed matches.  I get it, I understand it, there is nothing that can be said I haven't seen/heard on the issue.  I do not want to be a man hitting a woman.  I want to be a woman hitting a man.  Specifically, Stephanie McMahon.   Beating Brock Lesner.  What's your problem?  The point of WWE video games is to create (or re-create) your dream matches with your favorite WWE characters, and Stephanie McMahon happens to be my favorite.  I can set males to be her enemies, but nothing ever comes of it.  We have Super Mario CAW's fighting Freddy Krueger CAW's.  It's not practical, it's not probable, it certainly isn't representative of WWE, but damn, is it enjoyable.  That's what made the classic games so great - you could have your serious recreations, or you could have totally insane stuff... or, you could be like me, and just want to have your favorite/created Diva be the face of your WWE game.  To ignore mixed matches does very little to protect women... in fact, it makes them appear more fragile.  Not including mixed matches as a possiblity speaks to the WWE's confidence in their current Diva's - both that their personalities are not strong enough to clash with their male counterparts in a digital space, and that their fanbase isn't large enough to want to do so.  Add to the fact that I have to hear Jerry "The King" Lawler spew his sexist comments during a Diva's match ("I may be too old for her, but she certainly isn't too young for me...") as a ring-side announcer, and I roll my eyes at the "respect women" excuse for no mixed matches.  I hate to make this such a political statement when I'm not really seeking equality on a grand scale, just a better game.  Ah, well, hopefully mods will fix this.-Universe can be redundant.  I'm okay with this, but I list it for those that may be curious.  I figure, Exhibition will be redundant eventually.  At least with Universe, there's a chance of seeing some good random match-ups.-Lack of notable faces.  No Charlotte Flair, no Dudley Boyz, no Sasha Banks, no Alberto Del Rio (so, no official League of Nations team).  Easily remedied through creation mode, but the over abundance of Triple H's and Undertakers makes you kinda wish these stars were included instead.-Undertaker from his Fred Durst years is the strongest 'Taker without tweaking him yourself.All in all, this is a terrific game, and you can make any Superstar/Diva you want the center of your Universe, albeit with a few warts.  It's been a good minute since I've felt this freedom in a WWE game (pre-SvR and DoR titles), and I've never felt it to the extent I have in 2K16.  Couple this with the gameplay, and I can see myself playing this for years to come... unless 2K17 greatly expands on it (fingers crossed... 2K15->2K16 was a considerable leap).

This game is everything 2K15 should've been. It fixes a lot of the faults that 2K15 had, plus it is way better optimized for the PC than than 2K15 was. If you decide to buy 2K15 but not this I will punch you in the face!Also, if you are getting stuttering during entrances like I was, I (sort of) found a fix. Go to your documents folder (under C:\Users\[insert name here]\Documents\WWE2K16) and go into the config.ini file. 												Awful game do not buy.I decided against my better judgement to give wrestling games a try again, what a mistake that was. The port is very poor, the game always launches in windowed mode regardless of what you have it set to, there's tonnes of screen tearing even with v-sync on and entrances can very often tank the fps. While the roster is very large there are some glaring omissions like Kurt Angle, Eddie Guerrero, Rey Mysterio, Rob Van Dam and Hulk Hogan, however Hogan is a more complicated issue. many of the characters are not in career mode and are mostly just there for free play. The In ring gameplay is ok some of the new systems like the submission mechanic are downright awful but for the most part it's ok.Career mode is where i spent most of my time. You start out in NXT and slowly climb the ranks till you face Finn Balor for the NXT title and then you are moved up to the main roster and can choose a belt to go after, The ambitious man that i am i went for the WWE title. For a while career mode was good i had a storyline since I'd come up from NXT which basically boiled down to the authority thinking i wasn't good enough. on the way to my first pay per view i had lots of cutscenes and interviews that helped develop the storyline which culminated in a ppv match against big show and kane. After that the story continues and advances to Triple H attacking me himself and running in on my matches, again lots of cutscenes and interviews to advance the storyline which ended with a hell in a cell match against Triple H where i pedigreed Triple H through the cell ceiling. This is where career mode took a turn for the worse, by this point i was pretty happy with career mode I'd had a good storyline and good matches but that all ended here. After the hell in a cell match i had no more storylines no more cutscenes nothing i was 4th in ranking for the title at this point and i was just playing matches against the likes of Ryback and Mark Henry over and over. Sometimes a wrestler would run in on my match and it would start a feud but after the run in it's back to the same old random matches and then i got a normal match at the ppv with a rival I'd have had no buildup for. Then the next night on raw the same wrestler i just ended a rivalry with comes out and starts it again so it's another month of the same match over and over to end in a ppv with no storyline or buildup.By this point i was getting pretty bored of career mode and was considering uninstalling the game when i saw the next PPV was the royal rumble and i thought there's a storyline to be made there, then i got in a rivalry and thought ok i can eliminate this guy at the rumble and get the title shot this might be ok. Then the royal rumble came along and i saw i wasn't in the rumble even though i was the number 3 contender for the title, after some frantic googling to find out why it turns out if you are in a rivalry you can't do any special matches at a ppv so no money in the bank no royal rumble which is the dumbest thing I've ever seen if you made it so no one in a feud could be in the rumble then there would be like 3 people.By this point i thought well ok I'll get in a feud with the rumble winner and make the title match a triple threat, well you can't do that either because the game doesn't tell you who won the rumble. After some more googling i found out it doesn't matter anyway because apparently the AI doesn't cash in money in the bank and doesn't take the rumble title shot so i thought I'll play till mania and get in a feud with the title holder then it happens... the message you are locked in a rivalry with a mystery opponent pops up I'm thinking ok another actual storyline this might be ok. Well as it turns out it was Triple H, i started getting the exact same cutscenes as when i started the game so i was playing through the single storyline this game has twice instead of getting the title shot at mania. After that i decided to just skip all my matches until money in the bank and go that route. I remembered not to get in a rivalry with anyone before it so i could be in the ladder match and on the day of the ppv I'm in a normal match with Kane even though i'm the number 1 contender.The reason I'm telling this story is because anyone buying this game should know what they are in for a grind fest playing the same matches every week, no storylines, broken mechanics, and the game ♥♥♥♥ing you every time you try to make a storyline yourself.The career mode was very obviously rushed out the door and not play tested because anyone who is even a casual fan of wrestling would pick up on some of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t in this mode like the fact that once you turn heel it's impossible to turn face, it considers hitting someone with a chair in the Tables Ladders and Chairs match a heel move, if you get thrown out of the ring the game acts like you ran out the ring and it's counted as a heel move however there's nothing the game considers a face action to counteract this. The pay per views are laughable most of the ppvs in the game none of the titles are defended and at night of champions the one where all titles are defended one is defended. You have to be very lucky to be in a special match 99% of the time you will be in a normal 1v1 match regardless of whether it's mania, extreme rules, hell in a cell or the rumble.The custom wrestler creator is decent not great and once you've made your wrestler be prepared to shell out money for the skill boost or start out unable to wrestle.The only really good thing about this game is the entrance maker and even then you have to get a 3rd party program to get custom music for your entrance. Avoid this game at all costs unless you want Maggle Cole telling you how great it is to be on monday night raw even more than he already does.

												A good PC port, if lacking in graphics options such as model, object and environment detail, but is a much better improvement over the previous game. I'm not a wrestling fan, but even I love this game, with its vast customisation, game modes, character roster and sheer amount of replay value is incredible.Running at a locked 60 fps, WWE 2K16 sees the return of many favourite game modes, like create-an-arena, create-a-diva, match types, a whole new career mode and much more. The graphics seem better than WWE 2K15, especially with the character models and costume textures. Gameplay wise, I'm loving all the match types and going into the options menu to change rules, game hints, blood on/off and so forth. And speaking of, I also love the new mini-game-like QTEs that happen when actions like a pin, or grapple, occur. It adds a simple layer of 'fun' on-top of what is already a fun, meaty game. I love making my own movesets with my characters, making an entrance for them, and an arena for them to battle in. It's just incredibly fun and you'll be here for triple digit hours with it all!I haven't tried online, so this is an offline review. Having said that, a couple of things I want to see added in for the inevitable sequel is better audio design. What I mean is - I want to hear the occasional character scream or grunt as they pull off certain moves; giving it immersion by proportioning realism onto what is already a realistic game. Also minor, yet near-essential things like hearing footstep noises, climbing the ladder/cages, more variety in 'punch' sounds beyond the generic slap noise. And finally, better flowing commentary: it's quite jarring hearing the commentary suddenly cut-out to talk about something else I'm doing without finishing the previous sentence.Overall, as I said, I'm not a wrestling fan at all and I doubt this game will turn me to one, but I'm very much enjoying my time with this game. Perhaps a little more violence wouldn't hurt with enhanced persistent character damage, floors being scuffed and whatnot as per real wrestling. Having said that, this is a much better, improved, real letter to the fans that were left disappointed by the previous iteration or like me, just lost interest after so many features were dropped.Recommend to people who enjoy sports, brawlers, RPGs, simulators and action. Worth the £35 asking price? Definitely!

VS CONSOLEI've played this game previously on the Xbox One. According to the Xbox, I have played at least 264 hours on it. So how does the PC version stand up to the console version? I think it holds up very well. The game does have a few crashing problems for me, but so did the console version. The PC version also loads up 10x quicker than console. It would literally take a minute or more to load into a match on the console. For PC, it takes about 10 seconds.GAMEPLAYIf you're looking for an arcade like wrestling game, I'd suggest looking for a different title. But for someone looking to play a wrestling simulation just like the TV show, you will love this game. The pacing in matches is fairly slow to start off as you perform lock ups. You then transition into your normal grapples, leading into back and forth action. You have limited reversal, so you have to use your reversals wisely. As you get into the big heavy hitting moves, you start to feel the exhaustion as your wrestler fights with every last strength they have. Every time you kick out from a person's finisher, you feel like you're out of breath as you and your opponent can't believe you still have fight left in you. Believe me when I say, you will feel extremely satisfied when you kick out of a finisher without using your resiliency. And honestly, it's hard to get upset after losing a match when you know you put up one h*ll of a show.CREATIONSFor creations mode, you have a decent variety of things to create. You can create your own Wrestler (Cool looking or just plain wacky), you can create your own title belt, your own arena, your own show, and unlike 2K15, you can create your own Woman Wrestler (or Diva, as WWE likes to call them...). The customization for your wrestlers are very good. I have been able to create some very life like wrestlers, especially with the face import tool (where you can import any face you want and use them for your created wrestler). Create a move-set is still there of course. Create an entrance is better this year, with nearly every wrestler's entrance as an option, as opposed to very little. Unfortunately, still no custom themes (but there are mods for that...)MYCAREERHonestly, I played this on the console version and was VERY bored with it. Very rarely have I ever gotten cutscenes and storylines. Aside from the mandatory feud with Tyler Breeze in the beginning. I don't quite have much to say for this mode since I kind of skipped out on it. I'm currently trying to go through it again for PC. So, hopefully I can give you updates on my thoughts for it.UNIVERSE MODESame sh*t as the previous years, nothing has changed, lol. You run your shows, create feuds. Get occasional cutscenes.

												First Impressions Review:I think WWE 2K16 is an improvement over WWE 2K15 but it still has a lot of issues.What's Better:1) Create-A-Diva: '15 left out Diva creation '16 brought it in. Nice to know that 2K stopped being sexist.2) In-match optimization better: I no longer have the stuttering and performance issues during the match as I did with '15.3) Story Mode: They added a LOT to story mode, including rivalries, allies, picking which championship you want to go for, who you want to invade, all sorts of stuff! It's still got a grind factor, but there's a lot more depth in '16 than there was in '15.4) Match depth: There's a little more in-depth match mechanics like the various grappling mechanics which involve a back-and-forth mini-game of who can find the "sweet spot" first. But the game doesn't really tell you how to set that up...What's The Same:1) Graphics: Virtually the same engine. The audience is slightly improved. Superstars and the scenery are pretty much the same. Maybe some minor improvements...2) Overall fighting mechanics: Same huge sets of moves that are hard to perfect and rememberWhat's Worse:1) Submission: The submission mechanic is horrible. The system works like this: The defender has a blue bar, the aggressor has a red bar. The aggressor wants to have their red bar inside the defender's blue bar to fill up the circle in the center. If the circle is filled, the defender taps out. If it becomes completely blue, then the defender kicks out. Sounds fair, right? WRONG! If the body part is undamaged or fully damaged there's no real adjustment to how the mechanic works. It's all skill-based. I can understand that the bars should initially be based off of the wrestler's skills. But as the match goes on, there should be an equalizer. If you damage a body part, the aggressor should have an equalizer to help them get the submission win. What's the point of damaging a body part if you can't even take advantage of it...2) AI Kick-Outs: The AI kicks out ALL THE F*CKING TIME! An opponent I was against had no health, no stamina, just got Finishered, but STILL KICKED OUT BEFORE 3! This wasn't even the first time I had done the Special/Finisher combo. How are you supposed to win a match when the AI just magically kicks out ALL DAY LONG???? Then when the AI pins you, I don't even get a chance to kick out on the 1st count, have a tiny little zone for the 2nd and 3rd counts... The imba is real...3) Match Rating: The match rating was an issue with '15 and it's even worse in '16. They provide you with a meter in the HUD so you can see how "well" you're doing. Unfortunately, if you do a move once, it can no longer give you points for "variety." This game punishes you for using a move twice... Seriously? It should at least be diminishing returns instead of "you can use a move once, after that, too bad!" I guess the game really wants you to focus on ALL of those moves you picked in the character creation screen...For the $25 I paid for it, it's worth it so far. I hope '17 can address some of the issues that '16 has and finally get rid of those nagging issues leftover. Seriously, get rid of the match rating or make it actually worth having as a mechanic. I could get 4 and 5 star matches on '15 and I can't get above 3.5 stars in '16.

												Haven't regularly played a wrestling game since Smackdown! 2 on the Playstation. Saw a good deal on WWE2k16, figured what the heck, I'll try it. There's a lot to like in the game, but matches can often go from fun to absolutely infuriating based on the dumbest things. I get that handicap matches are supposed to put the player at a disadvantage, but there should not be the *added* disadvantage of having the game ignore you when you're trying to target a specific opponent. For example, in the Showcase, there's a Stone Cold vs. Vince and Shane McMahon ladder match. I can't even count how many times I would turn Austin towards Shane and try to strike or grapple, only to have Austin magically spin around and flail in Vince's direction. The game's decision for when you can or can't target someone seems completely arbitrary.Similarly, attempting to grapple an opponent standing right in front of me works 90% of the time, but 10% of the time, inexplicably, my character just sits there doing nothing, allowing the opponent to recover, often costing me the match. This is inexcusable.On top of that is the counter system, which basically turns every match into a game of chicken to see who's going to blink first. If I have four counters, and my opponent has four counters, the first one to use a counter is at an *immediate* disadvantage for the remainder of the match. For example, let's say Austin vs. Rock, each with four counters. If I'm Austin and I counterattack to get out of a bad situation, Rock has 4, and I have 3. That means my BEST CASE SCENARIO is Rock counters (3,3), I counter (2,3), Rock counters (2,2), I counter (1,2), Rock counters, (1,1), I counter (0,1), Rock counters (0,0). We're now both empty, but because he got the last counter, he has absolute control of the match, and I can basically just put my controller down and walk away for a minute or two, because I can't do ANYTHING. Counters recharge over time, but as soon as I've regenerated one, he's regenerated one too, and he's still controlling the match, which means I HAVE to use mine first, but as soon as I do, he'll use his, and he's back in control again. There's actually some strategy into how this can work in a tag team match or triple threat (though those come with the targeting/nonsense mentioned above), but in a singles match, the counter system effectively punishes whoever uses it first. On top of all that, the game either has no real tutorial, or has hidden it well. The NXT career and Showcase modes offer some tips, but leave others out, and there seems to be no rhyme or reason to what is and isn't taught. For example, the game teaches you the submission minigame, but never teaches you how to actually start a submission on an opponent. It teaches you the collar-and-elbow tie-up minigame, but never teaches you how to initiate a collar-and-elbow tie-up. Never tells you how to climb ladders or cages. Never tells you how to target another opponent.It's frustrating, because when the game isn't being super ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ annoying, it can actually be fun! But the moment your character randomly decides not to grapple when you're telling him to, or decides to target someone outside the ring instead of the opponent standing next to him in the ring, the fun instantly stops; all that's left is yelling at your monitor.

This is my first wrestling game since 2002.It was on sale for 75% off so i thought why not.I had looked at all the negative reviews,but seeing as i just wanted abit of fun like the old days i decided it would be ok.WRONG!The controls are atrocious,back on the old games in the 1990s to early 2000s the controls seemed more action oriented.More fluid, The amount of fun me and a friend used to have playing TLC matches was staggering.Constant on your seat intense jumping around excitement. Technology is the culprit here, now they can do more advanced motion capture,they try to make it as real as possible,and that's where i see the problem.For me it needs to be more fluid, more action oriented. 												I used to play wrestling games on the N64 and I haven't liked any of the newer ones I had tried, but I heard 2k16 was supposed to go back to the roots and try to make a better experience.  I personally didn't have any good experiences with it. First, when it is in full screen I still have a bar visible on the top and one side of the screen, it is annoying, but not a big deal.  For me the worst part of the game is the wrestling. It feels like the entire combat is based on reversals. The reversal system requires you to press a button at exactly the right time to reverse the move. It sounds ok, but by the time the indicator shows up to press the button it is too late if you try to anticipate it coming up it will say you pressed it too early.  This makes it very hard to successfully get a reversal and can mean you spend the entire fight trying to get a reversal or lose. My first match I only got one or two hits in the entire fight. Which, leads me to another issue there is no tutorial or training mode. Well, there is a tutorial, but you need to use a create a wrestler to do it, and there is no way (that I know of) to go through it again other than creating another new campaign. While you can make your own matches to practice with there is no dedicated training room like other fighting games have.  The pinning system is also very annoying. A wheel will pop up and start filling up you have to press a button to stop it while it is in a specific zone to kick out it sounds easy, but it goes so fast it is very hard. Now I've read a lot about the reversal and pinning issues online and most people seem to think you just need to keep playing to get used to the timing, well I didn't get to that point when I had a (for me) game breaking bug. I made a create a hero started doing the campaign and very shortly after I had an issue where it failed to save or let me load a save.  I tried every suggestion I found online except completely reinstalling (because if it happened once whats to stop it from happening again?) with no luck.  While looking online I saw someone lost a save with over a hundred hours on it. Fortunately, I only lost about an hour or so, but if this is happening to other people and with far more time invested than me, why should I or anyone else put time into it when we could lose it all to a bug that there is no known way to fix or prevent? Even if I could get adjusted to the reversal and pin system I cannot recommend a game that can randomly corrupt a save that people have put hours into.

Posted: January 3
												This game is a weird mix of good and bad. The character editor is good, and the various universe modes are solid. The showcase mode is also quite enjoyable. The MyCareer mode will remind you of every reason why so many people stopped watching WWE in 2015. Usos and Reigns are booked to be stronger than you, no matter how well you play the game. The authority henchmen will also march down to the ring and frequently harass you and cause you to lose matches, also mostly regardless of how well you can play. The gameplay itself is inconsistent, with button hits occasionally not registering. The timing is also terrible, with "too fast" and "too late" messages often appearing simultaneously. The manual is less helpful than a homeless alcoholic trying to give directions outside of a gas station, and you will almost certainly spend sometime googling basic things like "how to enter and exit the ring" and "how to climb the ropes". All in all, don't bother getting it unless it's on sale; it's not worth the list price.

												Oh god, where do i start with this game?First of all, I haven't played any WWE games since the PS3 titles like the ones with Smackdown vs. Raw kind.. so i was quite overwhelmed with the look and feel of this title. Cause this game could've been fun for me.. and it is fun played with a friend, but these three systems are outright terrible.I've only managed to try out the career mode a little and it seemed okay. Character creation feels limited though. There were enough match types to go through just to please any professional wrestling fan, but even they couldn't help save me to be on this game's side.Can i recommend the game? Not really, unless you accept these downsides of the gameplay. But to each their own, really.

												It's buggy but mostly fun. It's not amazing. I'm not really sure it's worth the 50 bucks even with all the DLC that puts it over 100 on other platforms, but it's fun if you want a good laugh. The controls are awkward and the collision handling is pretty terrible. If you want to climb the turn buckle, it's the same button to do so as it is to tag your partner in a tag-team match, so sometimes if you want to tag out, you'll climb the ropes instead. And speaking of climbing the ropes... in a battle royal? Wanna jump off the top rope onto somebody, but there's somebody pinning somebody else, no worries, it'll just slide them across the ring and out of your way as you hit them on your way down. Yup.Further issues include the targeting/locking system or whatever. Multiple people in the ring? Wanna switch targets? Well, by default, 'smart' targeting is on, which is hilarious as it basically means you can't switch targets. So you decide to turn it on manual switching... awesome, do it mid match, that's cool. Next match, however, it's back to default. So you change it outside battle, that's a pretty obvious fix, right? Only if you actually think that the targeting switching actually works. Guess what, half the time it doesn't. Woo!Then there's the graphics, oh man, they're interesting. It's very very obvious which "superstars" (still cracks me the hell up that WWE insists that all it's wrestlers, oh wait, can't call them that, are superstars), they spent the most time on. Most of the models for the incredibly lacking NXT roster are outright garbage. On top of that, any mid-carder, jobber, or female wrestler also look like they were made in a weekend. And that's not even mentioning what they did to poor Rene Young and her teeth. Good god almighty, she should sue.However, this is the biggest budget WWE game of all time supposedly, which isn't really a surprise, it just points to the fact that 2K games and the WWE don't take their fans or customers very seriously, and that the annual release schedule is untenable and leaves everybody with an unfinished/unpolished product. Hence why I said it's not worth the 50 bucks. I'm still going to give a 'yes' as to whether or not I'd recommend this game, but with a few caveats:1). Buy it on sale, preferably at 50% or more off.2). You need to like buggy games. Some of us find the bugs funny, so yes, that's a legit bullet point, if you don't like them, don't buy it.3). You probably need to like the WWE, a lot. Even if you liked the old WWF and WCW games that were actually great back in the day, and you want to play a modern version, this isn't it. Those games are still more fun, I just wish they had an updated roster and graphics.4). You need to have a high tolerance for repetitive and awful dialog. Michael Cole and JBL are involved so... yeah, and Renee Young's entire voice part is pretty much to say "and there you have it, back to you Michael Cole".
